climbs.name: Dulfer
climbs.fa: Georges Hampson, John Bret & Fritz Wiessner, 1943

content.description:
Starts a few meters to the right of the pinnacle at a right facing chimney with a large rectangular chock stone, and then follows a low angle left-facing corner with a crack. Leave the corner to follow a left facing flake to the left, then exit to the right towards a small tree.

Rappel down from bolted anchor.

Anchor at top

This route apparently has two (2) distinct cruxes with one through the sequence that lead to the roof, and the second one higher up.

Get to the ledge with which the route Hallucinorêve (5.11c) is shared with. Eye up for a few bolt passed two (2) good horizontal cracks and climb to the top of that. Figure out how to establish just right ionderneath the roof... i got shutted down here. Climb the roof and head into the second crux.

This is the line that break the middle of the smooth wall right of L'Aiguille.
Single to 0.75, slings

From atop the boulder that separates the routes right of the aiguille from the michael ward section preclip the draw on the corner.

Make three crimpy moves and gain a good stance to the right. Work your way up the corner handcrack the same open book that forms part of michael ward. If you move left there is a single bolt that protects the 12 which you do not need. Instead get a piece of gear and then go directly up the face passing two more bolts on nice 9/10 face climbing. 

it is possible to move the anchor from Michael Ward to give it a try.


The beginning is very height dependent.



big boulder 10 feet to the left of michael ward.

4 bolts. 2 bolt anchor. A few finger - hand cams for the middle.

A nice, if short, sport climb to the right of the needle.

Climb the small tooth shaped boulder to start on small crimps and nubby feet. Climb the face utilizing interesting side pulls until you come to a good rest below a small roof. Figure out the sequence and step up to a ledge where there is a two bolt anchor.

Just past the large boulder to the right and down the hill from l'aiguille
4 bolts, anchors at the top. Stick clip recommended.

Head up the face on the left side of the block, Traverse left under the roof to the corner of Fatman's Misery. Standard rack
exposed start.

Take the left side of the block, same as Fatman's but instead of traversing left at the roof, head straight over that block and the next one.

Single rack.

A Mega-Classic in the area. Some people say it has first been climbed without the bolts and using hiking boots. I am not entirely sure about this one though. The route start at the south jonction between "L'aiguille" and the main cliff. It's dead centre on the blank face. It actually start on a 10 feet high steep slab with a high bolt. Boulder up the slab on good holds, clip the bolt and mantle up to a large ledge. Scramble up easy ground angling left to a ledge with an horizontal crack, clip the second bolt. Take a little rest and get ready for the overhang. Climb up a crimpy section clipping two (2) more bolts until it is possible to get a rest out left on a less steep section. Climb on good holds to a thanks god horizontal crack. Place gear and traverse left under an arch which has a bolt above it. Climb up to the obvious side pull then clip the last bolt. Take a depth breath and fire the last section until you get to some very good holds at the base of a slab. The last section is unprotected but easy. You can use to flake on your right to get to the Anchor. to Camalot 0.75, leave the nuts

Five (5) bolts + Glue-in anchor

FA'd by Michael Ward while he was working in Montreal (he was the doctor on the first successful expedition on Everest) 
  
 Simply follow the corner up to a 2 bolt anchor 90 feet or so up.  
  
 Look for a rusty piton mid way up; planted there by Mr. Ward himself? Looks like it.


One of the first routes when coming in on the right of L'Aiguille. Look for the big left leaning crack just before a boulder you would have to squeeze through to pass by the cliff.

A very well protected climb with the crux at the very start.

Start in "Dulfer" then " Poussez Pas", at the horizontal crack continue straight ahead in a small finger crack. Commencez dans "Dulfer" puis "Poussez Pas", rendu à la fissure horizontale continuez tout droit dans une petite fissure à doigts. Just left of Hallucinoreve.

Juste a gauche d'Hallucinorève. Rack standard

The rightmost route on Mont Condor's right hand face. Aim for the big open book dihedral halfway up the cliff. Start in a small crack (5.7) to a first ledge, than climb a second small crack to the second ledge/slab that will lead you into the corner.

The guidebook has the rest as as an old-school 5.4 (second half of La Proposition) but my 6 y/o can climb Chico (5.4) and definitely can't climb this corner (5.6?). Slightly easier (5.5?) on top rope since you don't have to stay in the corner for protection.

La voie la plus à droite au Mont Condor. Viser le dièdre ouvert en milieu de parois. Utiliser deux petites craques successives bien protégées pour accéder aux deux vires (crux au départ en 5.7).

Une voie intéressante pour le niveau.

Ancrages difficile d'accès par le haut pour installer un top rope (requiert un rappel et une connaissance de la parois). Une directionnelle est aussi recommandée dans la deuxième craque depuis la base pour un top rope.

Access from the top to install a top rope is tricky (requires a rappel and knowledge of the cliff from above). A directional is also recommended for top rope.


Standard rack. Relais sur scellements.

Start in "Dulfer", after the ledge A piton indicates the beginning of the route. The route is a bit dirty but the moves are still very good. Commencez dans "Dulfer", après la vire restez à droite dans un dièdre vers la gauche. Un piton marque le début de la voie. La voie est un peu salle mais les mouvement se font encore très bien. Dihedral to the right of "Dulfer."

Dièdre à droite de "Dulfer" Standard rack + small protection for the last section.

Rack standard + petite protection pour la dernière section.

This area contains some steep face climbs, a few multi-pitch and some good old chimneys.

Ce secteur contient quelques ascensions de faces très raides, quelques multi-pitchs et quelques bonnes vieilles cheminées.
